title: R44392
content: The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. It can be used towards qualified health insurance, is refundable, and advanceable. To claim the HCTC, taxpayers must meet specific eligibility criteria. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) covers 72.5% of the premium for eligible taxpayers, who are responsible for the remaining 27.5%. Recipients of certain benefits under the Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) program and individuals aged 55-64 receiving payments from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) are eligible for the HCTC. TAA provides assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to international trade, and eligible workers can claim the HCTC if they receive specific TAA benefits. Workers certified for TAA benefits can receive the HCTC if they receive TRA or UI payments. RTAA provides a wage supplement for older workers who secure lower-paying jobs after TAA certification. RTAA is a wage supplement for workers aged 50 and older who were certified for TAA and secure qualified employment at a lower wage. It pays 50% of the wage difference for up to two years, with a maximum benefit of $10,000. ATAA is a similar wage-insurance program that existed before the recent TAA reauthorization. HCTC eligibility is limited to individuals receiving TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. Individuals eligible for HCTC must receive TRA, RTAA, or ATAA cash benefits. PBGC pays pensions to former workers from terminated defined-benefit plans. Eligible individuals for HCTC must be at least 55 years old. The PBGC pays pensions to former workers from terminated defined-benefit plans. Eligible individuals for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) must be at least 55 years old and not eligible for certain other health coverage programs. To be eligible for the Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC), individuals must not be eligible for Medicare Part A, Tricare, be incarcerated, or claimed as a dependent by another taxpayer. The HCTC can be used for health insurance covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Children of divorced or separated parents are considered dependents of the custodial parent. Family members face the same eligibility restrictions as the taxpayer. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can be used for health insurance covering the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. Family members may receive the HCTC for up to two years after certain events. Eligible taxpayers can only claim the HCTC for specific categories of coverage. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) can be used for specific categories of coverage, including automatically qualified health plans like COBRA, group health plans through a spouse's employer, individual health insurance, and coverage funded by VEBA. State-qualified health plans, such as state-based continuation coverage and coverage through a state high-risk pool, are also eligible if established by the state. State-qualified health plans, identified by statutory letter designations, include options like state-based continuation coverage, coverage through a state high-risk pool, and coverage under state-operated plans. These plans must provide consumer protections to qualifying individuals, defined as HCTC-eligible individuals. State-qualified health plans must provide four consumer protections to qualifying individuals, including guaranteed issue, coverage for preexisting conditions, equal premiums, and similar benefits. The Health Coverage Tax Credit program ensures that coverage cannot be denied based on preexisting conditions, premiums must be equal for qualifying individuals, and benefits must be similar to others. Certain types of coverage are not considered qualified health insurance under the program. The Health Coverage Tax Credit (HCTC) program, administered by the IRS, involves multiple federal and state agencies. The Department of the Treasury handles advance payments, the IRS reviews tax returns, and the DOL and PBGC help identify eligible individuals. State entities like SWAs also play a role in assisting job seekers with information about benefits like the HCTC. The One-Stop Career Center system provides services to assist job seekers, including information about benefits like the HCTC. State workforce agencies (SWAs) administer unemployment and TAA benefits. SWAs mail HCTC information packets to eligible TAA beneficiaries, including an eligibility certificate. The PBGC also identifies eligible beneficiaries and provides their information to the IRS, who then mails program kits to eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance. The HCTC is available to eligible taxpayers with qualified health insurance, who can claim the tax credit when filing their tax returns or receive advance payments monthly. The credit is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Choosing the HCTC does not affect eligibility for other tax credits, except for the premium tax credit. The credit is refundable, allowing taxpayers to receive the full amount they are eligible for, regardless of their tax liability. Other tax credits do not affect eligibility for the HCTC, except for the premium tax credit under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. IRS data shows that in tax year 2013, 13,693 tax returns claimed the HCTC, totaling approximately $52.3 million. In 2016, 13,015 e-filed tax returns claimed the credit. Taxpayers must complete Form 8885 and provide proof of payment for qualified health insurance to claim the HCTC. Taxpayers claiming the HCTC must complete Form 8885 and provide proof of payment for qualified health insurance. The credit amount reduces taxes owed and is refundable if it exceeds the tax liability. To receive advance payments, individuals register with the HCTC program and pay their share of the monthly premium. The HCTC program confirms eligibility, invoices for the taxpayer's share of the premium, and sends payments to health insurance plans. Payments include 27.5% from the individual and 72.5% from Treasury.
